name: Kepler-298
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-298 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-298 is a star with 0.47999999999999987 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.58 times its radius. It is located 1715.52 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-298 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-298 b

Kepler-298 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 10.48 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-298.

The mass of Kepler-298 b is 4.85 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-298 b is 1.96 that of Earth. At 4.85 Earth masses, Kepler-298 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-298 c

Kepler-298 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 22.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-298.

The mass of Kepler-298 c is 4.65 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-298 c is 1.93 that of Earth. At 4.65 Earth masses, Kepler-298 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-298 d

Kepler-298 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.30 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 77.47 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-298.

The mass of Kepler-298 d is 8.67 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-298 d is 2.5 that of Earth. At 8.67 Earth masses, Kepler-298 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

With a semi-major axis of 0.305 astronomical units, and a mass of 8.67 Earth masses, Kepler-298 d could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-298, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
